question.simpara: Why is it called Residual - what does this name mean?

answer.simpara: The ScummVM program can run LucasArts 2D SCUMM adventures (among others). Residual is named such as it aims to do the same for the residual (remaining) games. It is also a word pun, as the engine used in these LUA-based adventure is called GrimE (as opposed to SCUMM). Grime is a type of residue.
GrimE (Grim Engine) is an adventure game engine, created by Bret Mogilefsky at LucasArts using scripting language Lua. It was first used for Grim Fandango.

Residual is released under the GPL (General Public License), so it's more than free. Residual source code is freely available and you can do whatever you want with it. If you make modifications to it and redistribute your work you MUST make the source available. However, the Residual team would be pleased if you choose to send them your modifications, so they can be merged into the main tree.

question.simpara: On what platform does Residual run?

answer.simpara: Residual should be able to be compiled on any SDL platform, with modifications.
Currently tested platforms include Win32 (Windows 95/98/ME/NT/2000/XP), Linux i386 and PPC, Mac OS X, AmigaOS 4.
We have a compatibility list on our website that contains an up-to-date list of which games work, and how well they work.

question.simpara: How do I install games to run in Residual?

answer.simpara: For most games you do not need to run the installer. Simply copy the files listed here from your CD to your hard drive, then read instructions from README.

question.simpara: Can I run my game full screen?

answer.simpara: Yes. You can either start your game using the -f command line parameter, setting the game to Full Screen in the game options configuration file.

question.simpara: My game crashes at some point.

answer.simpara: Check the Compatibility List to see if your game has any known issues. For now please don't report bugs, the Grim engine is in still alpha state.

question.simpara: Residual crashes, but the console window disappears too quickly to see the error message.

answer.simpara: On Windows, to make it visible, you should run Residual from the command line. To open a command prompt, open the Start Menu and select the 'Run' option. Under Windows NT/2000/XP, type 'cmd.exe' (no quotes) in the dialog box that shows up; under Windows 95/98/Me, type 'command.com' instead. If necessary, change to the proper drive first by typing 'D:' (where 'D' is the drive Residual is located). Change to Residual's directory by typing 'cd \your\path\to\residual' (substituting the appropriate path) and then type 'residual'.

On MacOS X, you can find the error messages by starting Console.app (in Utilities within the Applications folder). If you prefer, you can also run Residual from the terminal. To do this, start Terminal.app (also in the Utilities folder), then drag&drop the Resdual.app application onto the Terminal window, remove the space at the end of the line and add 'Contents/MacOS/residual' (without the quotes). The line should look like this: '/Path/to/Residual.app/Contents/MacOS/residual'. Then press return to start Residual.

question.simpara: I get "WARNING: Unable to open configuration file C:\windows\residual.ini!"

answer.simpara: Make sure you have enough permissions to write in c:\windows directory. Also note that this warning the first time you run Residual, since the file does not exist yet then.

question.simpara: I get "Failed to save game state to file: xxx"

answer.simpara: Check savepath in residual config file. That should point to writable directory.

question.simpara: Residual starts, but all I get is a transparent window!

answer.simpara: This problem has been reported to happen under Windows in some cases. Check that you have the latest drivers for your graphics card. If that does not help, try setting the SDL_VIDEODRIVER environment variable to "windib" and try again.
Apparently other applications have had the same problem, because the release notes for SDL 1.2.10 (May 17, 2006) contained the following note:

blockquote.simpara: The "windib" video driver is the default now, to prevent problems with certain laptops, 64-bit Windows, and Windows Vista. The DirectX driver is still available, and can be selected by setting the environment variable SDL_VIDEODRIVER to "directx".

question.simpara: Residual runs, but sound is stuttering and/or garbled!

answer.simpara: This problem has been reported to happen under Windows in some cases. Check that you have the latest drivers for your sound card. If that does not help, try setting the SDL_AUDIODRIVER environment variable to "waveout" and try again.

question.simpara: How do I set an environment variable?

answer.simpara: That depends on what operating system and/or command shell you are using. Under Windows, you could try creating a file called residual.bat in the same folder as residual.exe. Open this file in your favorite text editor and put something like this in it:

blockquote.programlisting: @echo off set SDL_VIDEODRIVER=windib set SDL_AUDIODRIVER=waveout residual.exe %1 %2 %3 %4 %5 %6 %7 %8 %9

answer.simpara: You should now be able to run Residual by double-clicking on this batch file, instead of the Residual executable.
On more recent versions of Windows, you can also set an environment variable permanently, and for all applications, through the control panel.

question.simpara: Residual starts somewhere in the middle of my two Xinerama monitors in fullscreen mode. Help!

answer.simpara: In fact, this is SDL problem. SDL does by default has xinerama support enabled. Set the SDL_VIDEO_FULLSCREEN_HEAD environment variable to "1" to start Residual (and other SDL applications) in fullscreen on only one monitor. If this does not work make sure your SDL library does have Xinerama support compiled in.
